name: Spatial Computation via Turing Instability
description: The ability of a swarm to spontaneously generate complex spatial patterns (spots, stripes) from randomness using local Activator-Inhibitor rules.
hypothesis: Short-range Activation + Long-range Inhibition = Spatial Pattern
findings: Implemented a FitzHugh-Nagumo type Reaction-Diffusion model on the swarm.
With Bias=0 and Diffusion Ratio Dh/Da=50, the system spontaneously broke symmetry.
Stable high-contrast patterns emerged (Variance 0.89) from random noise.
This confirms the swarm can act as a 'Spatial Computer' to generate morphology.
implications: Swarms can self-organize into functional structures.
Morphogenesis can be driven by simple local chemical rules.
Distributed spatial memory and pattern formation are viable.
